unnormalised: ## Oh No, Not Again! The Great Cart Abandonment Kerfuffle
normalised: Oh No, Not Again! The Great Cart Abandonment Kerfuffle

unnormalised: Picture this: It's Diwali season. You're browsing your favourite e-commerce site, diligently adding sarees for your mom, a snazzy kurta for your chacha, and maybe, just maybe, that ridiculously oversized Ganesh statue you've been eyeing for months (Rs. 5000? Worth it!). You reach the checkout, ready to punch in your UPI ID… and then, BAM! Distraction strikes. Your neighbour, aunty Padma, bursts in with a plate of freshly made, ghee-dripping laddoos. Resistance is futile.

Resistance is futile.

unnormalised: The next thing you know, an hour has passed, you’re in a sugar-induced coma, and your shopping cart sits abandoned in the digital ether, a lonely monument to your fleeting consumerism. Sound familiar, friends? This, my friends, is the dreaded Cart Abandonment, and it's the bane of every online retailer's existence.

unnormalised: It's like inviting everyone over for a biryani feast, spending all day prepping the ingredients (high quality basmati, duh!), and then finding out no one showed up. Ouch.

unnormalised: So, why does this happen? Maybe the shipping cost (Rs. 150? Really?) suddenly transformed that amazing deal into a not-so-amazing one. Maybe the checkout process was longer than a trip from Delhi to Kanyakumari by bullock cart. Or maybe, just maybe, Padma aunty's laddoos were just too darn tempting.
normalised: So, why does this happen? Maybe the shipping cost (rupee one hundred and fifty? Really?) suddenly transformed that amazing deal into a not-so-amazing one. Maybe the checkout process was longer than a trip from Delhi to Kanyakumari by bullock cart. Or maybe, just maybe, Padma aunty's laddoos were just too darn tempting.

unnormalised: Whatever the reason, abandoned carts are a serious issue. But fear not! Retailers are fighting back with tempting reminders, free shipping offers, and even the occasional personalized email with a virtual "Nazar utaro!" to ward off bad shopping karma. So next time you find yourself abandoning your cart, remember those poor, lonely items, yearning to be delivered to your doorstep. And maybe, just maybe, think twice before accepting that second helping of laddoo. Unless, of course, it's Onam and there's Payasam involved. Then all bets are off.
